What would be the exit velocity, in $\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}$, if the isentropic nozzle efficiency were $90 \%$ ? Ans. $592 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$.

# 12.4.2 Mixing of Ideal Gases 

Thus far, we have considered only mixtures that have already been formed. Now let us take up cases where ideal gas mixtures are formed by mixing gases that are initially separate. Such mixing is irreversible because the mixture forms spontaneously, and a work input from the surroundings would be required to separate the gases and return them to their respective initial states. In this section, the irreversibility of mixing is demonstrated through calculations of the entropy production.

Three factors contribute to the production of entropy in mixing processes:

1. The gases are initially at different temperatures.
2. The gases are initially at different pressures.
3. The gases are distinguishable from one another.

Entropy is produced when any of these factors is present during a mixing process. This is illustrated in the next example, where different gases, initially at different temperatures and pressures, are mixed.

## EXAMPLE 12.5 | Investigating Adiabatic Mixing of Gases at Constant Total Volume

Two rigid, insulated tanks are interconnected by a valve. Initially 0.79 lbmol of nitrogen at 2 atm and $460^{\circ} \mathrm{R}$ fills one tank. The other tank contains 0.21 lbmol of oxygen at 1 atm and $540^{\circ} \mathrm{R}$. The valve is opened and the gases are allowed to mix until a final equilibrium state is attained. During this process, there are no heat or
work interactions between the tank contents and the surroundings. Determine (a) the final temperature of the mixture, in ${ }^{\circ} \mathrm{R}$, (b) the final pressure of the mixture, in atm, (c) the amount of entropy produced in the mixing process, in $\mathrm{Btu} /{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{R}$.
## Solution

Known Nitrogen and oxygen, initially separate at different temperatures and pressures, are allowed to mix without heat or work interactions with the surroundings until a final equilibrium state is attained.

Find Determine the final temperature of the mixture, in ${ }^{\circ} \mathrm{R}$, the final pressure of the mixture, in atm, and the amount of entropy produced in the mixing process, in Btu/ ${ }^{\circ} \mathrm{R}$.

## Schematic and Given Data:



FIG. E12.5

## Engineering Model

1. The system is taken to be the nitrogen and the oxygen together.
2. When separate, each of the gases behaves as an ideal gas.
3. The final mixture acts as an ideal gas and the Dalton model applies: Each mixture component occupies the total volume and exhibits the mixture temperature.
4. No heat or work interactions occur with the surroundings, and there are no changes in kinetic and potential energy.

## Analysis

a. The final temperature of the mixture can be determined from an energy balance. With assumption 4, the closed system energy balance reduces to

$$
\Delta U=\wp^{0}-\mathscr{H}^{0} \quad \text { or } \quad U_{2}-U_{1}=0
$$

The initial internal energy of the system, $U_{1}$, equals the sum of the internal energies of the two gases when separate

$$
U_{1}=n_{\mathrm{N}_{1}} \bar{u}_{\mathrm{N}_{1}}\left(T_{\mathrm{N}_{2}}\right)+n_{\mathrm{O}_{2}} \bar{u}_{\mathrm{O}_{2}}\left(T_{\mathrm{O}_{2}}\right)
$$

where $T_{\mathrm{N}_{2}}=460^{\circ} \mathrm{R}$ is the initial temperature of the nitrogen and $T_{\mathrm{O}_{2}}=540^{\circ} \mathrm{R}$ is the initial temperature of the oxygen. The final internal energy of the system, $U_{2}$, equals the sum of the internal energies of the two gases evaluated at the final mixture temperature $T_{2}$

$$
U_{2}=n_{\mathrm{N}_{2}} \bar{u}_{\mathrm{N}_{2}}\left(T_{2}\right)+n_{\mathrm{O}_{2}} \bar{u}_{\mathrm{O}_{2}}\left(T_{2}\right)
$$

Collecting the last three equations

$$
n_{\mathrm{N}_{1}}\left[\bar{u}_{\mathrm{N}_{2}}\left(T_{2}\right)-\bar{u}_{\mathrm{N}_{2}}\left(T_{\mathrm{N}_{2}}\right)\right]+n_{\mathrm{O}_{2}}\left[\bar{u}_{\mathrm{O}_{2}}\left(T_{2}\right)-\bar{u}_{\mathrm{O}_{2}}\left(T_{\mathrm{O}_{2}}\right)\right]=0
$$

The temperature $T_{2}$ can be determined using specific internal energy data from Table A-23E and an iterative procedure like that employed in part (a) of Example 12.4. However, since the specific heats of $\mathrm{N}_{2}$ and $\mathrm{O}_{2}$ vary little over the temperature interval from 460 to $540^{\circ} \mathrm{R}$, the solution can be conducted accurately on the
basis of constant specific heats. Hence, the foregoing equation becomes

$$
n_{\mathrm{N}_{2}} \bar{c}_{\mathrm{t} . \mathrm{N}_{2}}\left(T_{2}-T_{\mathrm{N}_{2}}\right)+n_{\mathrm{O}_{2}} \bar{c}_{\mathrm{t} . \mathrm{O}_{2}}\left(T_{2}-T_{\mathrm{O}_{2}}\right)=0
$$

Solving for $T_{2}$

$$
T_{2}=\frac{n_{\mathrm{N}_{2}} \bar{c}_{\mathrm{t} . \mathrm{N}_{2}} T_{\mathrm{N}_{2}}+n_{\mathrm{O}_{2}} \bar{c}_{\mathrm{t} . \mathrm{O}_{2}} T_{\mathrm{O}_{2}}}{n_{\mathrm{N}_{2}} \bar{c}_{\mathrm{t} . \mathrm{N}_{2}}+n_{\mathrm{O}_{2}} \bar{c}_{\mathrm{t} . \mathrm{O}_{2}}}
$$

Selecting $c_{\mathrm{s}}$ values for $\mathrm{N}_{2}$ and $\mathrm{O}_{2}$ from Table A-20E at the average of the initial temperatures of the gases, $500^{\circ} \mathrm{R}$, and using the respective molecular weights to convert to a molar basis

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \bar{c}_{\mathrm{t} . \mathrm{N}_{2}}=\left(28.01 \frac{\mathrm{lb}}{\mathrm{lbmol}}\right)\left(0.177 \frac{\mathrm{Btu}}{\mathrm{lb} \cdot{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{R}}\right)=4.96 \frac{\mathrm{Btu}}{\mathrm{lbmol} \cdot{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{R}} \\
& \bar{c}_{\mathrm{t} . \mathrm{O}_{2}}=\left(32.0 \frac{\mathrm{lb}}{\mathrm{lbmol}}\right)\left(0.156 \frac{\mathrm{Btu}}{\mathrm{lb} \cdot{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{R}}\right)=4.99 \frac{\mathrm{Btu}}{\mathrm{lbmol} \cdot{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{R}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Substituting values into the expression for $T_{2}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& (0.79 \mathrm{lbmol})\left(4.96 \frac{\mathrm{Btu}}{\mathrm{lbmol} \cdot{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{R}}\right)\left(460^{\circ} \mathrm{R}\right) \\
& T_{2}=\frac{+}{(0.79 \mathrm{lbmol})\left(4.99 \frac{\mathrm{Btu}}{\mathrm{lbmol} \cdot{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{R}}\right)}\left(540^{\circ} \mathrm{R}\right)}{(0.79 \mathrm{lbmol})\left(4.96 \frac{\mathrm{Btu}}{\mathrm{lbmol} \cdot{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{R}}\right)} \\
& +(0.21 \mathrm{lbmol})\left(4.99 \frac{\mathrm{Btu}}{\mathrm{lbmol} \cdot{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{R}}\right) \\
& =477^{\circ} \mathrm{R}
\end{aligned}
$$

b. The final mixture pressure $p_{2}$ can be determined using the ideal gas equation of state, $p_{2}=n \bar{R} T_{2} / V$, where $n$ is the total number of moles of mixture and $V$ is the total volume occupied by the mixture. The volume $V$ is the sum of the volumes of the two tanks, obtained with the ideal gas equation of state as follows:

$$
V=\frac{n_{\mathrm{N}_{2}} \bar{R} T_{\mathrm{N}_{2}}}{p_{\mathrm{N}_{2}}}+\frac{n_{\mathrm{O}_{2}} \bar{R} T_{\mathrm{O}_{2}}}{p_{\mathrm{O}_{2}}}
$$

where $p_{\mathrm{N}_{2}}=2 \mathrm{~atm}$ is the initial pressure of the nitrogen and $p_{\mathrm{O}_{2}}=1 \mathrm{~atm}$ is the initial pressure of the oxygen. Combining results and reducing

$$
p_{2}=\frac{\left(n_{\mathrm{N}_{2}}+n_{\mathrm{O}_{2}}\right) T_{2}}{\left(\frac{n_{\mathrm{N}_{2}} T_{\mathrm{N}_{2}}}{p_{\mathrm{N}_{2}}}+\frac{n_{\mathrm{O}_{2}} T_{\mathrm{O}_{2}}}{p_{\mathrm{O}_{2}}}\right)}
$$

Substituting values

$$
\begin{aligned}
p_{2} & =\frac{(1.0 \mathrm{lbmol})\left(477^{\circ} \mathrm{R}\right)}{\left(\frac{(0.79 \mathrm{lbmol})\left(460^{\circ} \mathrm{R}\right)}{2 \mathrm{~atm}}+\frac{(0.21 \mathrm{lbmol})\left(540^{\circ} \mathrm{R}\right)}{1 \mathrm{~atm}}\right]} \\
& =1.62 \mathrm{~atm}
\end{aligned}
$$

c. Reducing the closed system form of the entropy balance

$$
S_{2}-S_{1}=\int_{P}^{2}\left(\frac{\delta \mathscr{L}}{T}\right)_{h}^{0}+\sigma
$$
where the entropy transfer term drops out for the adiabatic mixing process. The initial entropy of the system, $S_{1}$, is the sum of the entropies of the gases at the respective initial states

$$
S_{1}=n_{\mathrm{N}_{1}} \bar{s}_{\mathrm{N}_{1}}\left(T_{\mathrm{N}_{1}}, p_{\mathrm{N}_{1}}\right)+n_{\mathrm{O}_{2}} \bar{s}_{\mathrm{O}_{2}}\left(T_{\mathrm{O}_{2}}, p_{\mathrm{O}_{2}}\right)
$$

The final entropy of the system, $S_{2}$, is the sum of the entropies of the individual components, each evaluated at the final mixture temperature and the partial pressure of the component in the mixture

$$
S_{2}=n_{\mathrm{N}_{1}} \bar{s}_{\mathrm{N}_{1}}\left(T_{2}, y_{\mathrm{N}_{1}} p_{2}\right)+n_{\mathrm{O}_{2}} \bar{s}_{\mathrm{O}_{2}}\left(T_{2}, y_{\mathrm{O}_{2}} p_{2}\right)
$$

Collecting the last three equations

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sigma= & n_{\mathrm{N}_{1}}\left[\bar{s}_{\mathrm{N}_{1}}\left(T_{2}, y_{\mathrm{N}_{1}} p_{2}\right)-\bar{s}_{\mathrm{N}_{1}}\left(T_{\mathrm{N}_{1}}, p_{\mathrm{N}_{1}}\right)\right] \\
& +n_{\mathrm{O}_{2}}\left[\bar{s}_{\mathrm{O}_{2}}\left(T_{2}, y_{\mathrm{O}_{2}} p_{2}\right)-\bar{s}_{\mathrm{O}_{2}}\left(T_{\mathrm{O}_{2}}, p_{\mathrm{O}_{2}}\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Evaluating the change in specific entropy of each gas in terms of a constant specific heat $\bar{c}_{p}$, this becomes

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sigma= & n_{\mathrm{N}_{1}}\left(\bar{c}_{p, \mathrm{~N}_{2}} \ln \frac{T_{2}}{T_{\mathrm{N}_{1}}}-\bar{R} \ln \frac{y_{\mathrm{N}_{1}} p_{2}}{p_{\mathrm{N}_{1}}}\right) \\
& +n_{\mathrm{O}_{2}}\left(\bar{c}_{p, \mathrm{O}_{2}} \ln \frac{T_{2}}{T_{\mathrm{O}_{2}}}-\bar{R} \ln \frac{y_{\mathrm{O}_{2}} p_{2}}{p_{\mathrm{O}_{2}}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The required values for $\bar{c}_{p}$ can be found by adding $\bar{R}$ to the $\bar{c}_{v}$ values found previously (Eq. 3.45)

$$
\bar{c}_{p, \mathrm{~N}_{2}}=6.95 \frac{\mathrm{Btu}}{\mathrm{lbmol} \cdot{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{R}}, \quad \bar{c}_{p, \mathrm{O}_{2}}=6.98 \frac{\mathrm{Btu}}{\mathrm{lbmol} \cdot{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{R}}
$$

Since the total number of moles of mixture $n=0.79+0.21=1.0$, the mole fractions of the two gases are $y_{\mathrm{N}_{2}}=0.79$ and $y_{\mathrm{O}_{2}}=0.21$.

Substituting values into the expression for $\sigma$ gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sigma= & 0.79 \mathrm{lbmol}\left[6.95 \frac{\mathrm{Btu}}{\mathrm{lbmol} \cdot{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{R}} \ln \left(\frac{477^{\circ} \mathrm{R}}{460^{\circ} \mathrm{R}}\right)\right. \\
& \left.-1.986 \frac{\mathrm{Btu}}{\mathrm{lbmol} \cdot{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{R}} \ln \left(\frac{(0.79)(1.62 \mathrm{~atm})}{2 \mathrm{~atm}}\right)\right] \\
& +0.21 \mathrm{lbmol}\left[6.98 \frac{\mathrm{Btu}}{\mathrm{lbmol} \cdot{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{R}} \ln \left(\frac{477^{\circ} \mathrm{R}}{540^{\circ} \mathrm{R}}\right)\right. \\
& \left.-1.986 \frac{\mathrm{Btu}}{\mathrm{lbmol} \cdot{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{R}} \ln \left(\frac{(0.21)(1.62 \mathrm{~atm})}{1 \mathrm{~atm}}\right)\right] \\
& =1.168 \mathrm{Btu} /{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{R}
\end{aligned}
$$

(3) Entropy is produced when different gases, initially at different temperatures and pressures, are allowed to mix.

# EXAMPLE 12.6 | Analyzing Adiabatic Mixing of Two Streams 

At steady state, $100 \mathrm{~m}^{3} / \mathrm{min}$ of dry air at $32^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and 1 bar is mixed adiabatically with a stream of oxygen $\left(\mathrm{O}_{2}\right)$ at $127^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and 1 bar to form a mixed stream at $47^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and 1 bar. Kinetic and potential energy effects can be ignored. Determine (a) the mass flow rates of the dry air and oxygen, in $\mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{min}$, (b) the mole fractions of the dry air and oxygen in the exiting mixture, and (c) the time rate of entropy production, in $\mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{K} \cdot \mathrm{min}$.

## Solution

Known At steady state, $100 \mathrm{~m}^{3} / \mathrm{min}$ of dry air at $32^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and 1 bar is mixed adiabatically with an oxygen stream at $127^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and 1 bar to form a mixed stream at $47^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and 1 bar.

Find Determine the mass flow rates of the dry air and oxygen, in $\mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{min}$, the mole fractions of the dry air and oxygen in the exiting mixture, and the time rate of entropy production, in $\mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{K} \cdot \mathrm{min}$.

## Schematic and Given Data:



FIG. S12.6

## Engineering Model

1. The control volume identified by the dashed line on the accompanying figure operates at steady state.
2. No heat transfer occurs with the surroundings.
3. Kinetic and potential energy effects can be ignored, and $\dot{W}_{\mathrm{c} 1}=0$.
4. The entering gases can be regarded as ideal gases. The exiting mixture can be regarded as an ideal gas mixture adhering to the Dalton model.
5. The dry air is treated as a pure component.

## Analysis

a. The mass flow rate of the dry air entering the control volume can be determined from the given volumetric flow rate $(\mathrm{AV})_{\mathrm{I}}$

$$
\dot{m}_{\mathrm{a} 1}=\frac{(\mathrm{AV})_{\mathrm{I}}}{\mathrm{v}_{\mathrm{a} 1}}
$$

where $v_{\mathrm{a} 1}$ is the specific volume of the air at 1 . Using the ideal gas equation of state

$$
v_{\mathrm{a} 1}=\frac{\left(\widetilde{R} / M_{\mathrm{a}}\right) T_{1}}{p_{1}}=\frac{\left(\frac{8314 \mathrm{~N} \cdot \mathrm{~m}}{28.97 \mathrm{~kg} \cdot \mathrm{~K}}\right)(305 \mathrm{~K})}{10^{5} \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}^{2}}=0.875 \frac{\mathrm{~m}^{3}}{\mathrm{~kg}}
$$

The mass flow rate of the dry air is then

$$
\dot{m}_{\mathrm{a} 1}=\frac{100 \mathrm{~m}^{3} / \mathrm{min}}{0.875 \mathrm{~m}^{3} / \mathrm{kg}}=114.29 \frac{\mathrm{~kg}}{\min }
$$

The mass flow rate of the oxygen can be determined using mass and energy rate balances. At steady state, the amounts of dry air and oxygen contained within the control volume do not vary. Thus, for each component individually it is necessary for the incoming and outgoing mass flow rates to be equal. That is,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \dot{m}_{\mathrm{a} 1}=\dot{m}_{\mathrm{a} 3} \\
& \text { (dry air) } \\
& \dot{m}_{\mathrm{o} 2}=\dot{m}_{\mathrm{o} 3}
\end{aligned}
$$

(oxygen)
Using assumptions 1-3 together with the foregoing mass flow rate relations, the energy rate balance reduces to

$$
0=\dot{m}_{\mathrm{a}} h_{\mathrm{o}}\left(T_{3}\right)+\dot{m}_{\mathrm{o}} h_{\mathrm{o}}\left(T_{2}\right)-\left[\dot{m}_{\mathrm{a}} h_{\mathrm{o}}\left(T_{3}\right)+\dot{m}_{\mathrm{o}} h_{\mathrm{o}}\left(T_{3}\right)\right]
$$

where $\dot{m}_{\mathrm{a}}$ and $\dot{m}_{\mathrm{o}}$ denote the mass flow rates of the dry air and oxygen, respectively. The enthalpy of the mixture at the exit is evaluated by summing the contributions of the air and oxygen, each at the mixture temperature. Solving for $\dot{m}_{\mathrm{o}}$

$$
\dot{m}_{\mathrm{o}}=\dot{m}_{\mathrm{a}}\left[\frac{h_{\mathrm{a}}\left(T_{3}\right)-h_{\mathrm{o}}\left(T_{3}\right)}{h_{\mathrm{o}}\left(T_{2}\right)-h_{\mathrm{o}}\left(T_{3}\right)}\right]
$$

The specific enthalpies can be obtained from Tables A-22 and A-23. Since Table A-23 gives enthalpy values on a molar basis, the molecular weight of oxygen is introduced into the denominator to convert the molar enthalpy values to a mass basis

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \dot{m}_{\mathrm{o}}=\frac{(114.29 \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{min})(320.29 \mathrm{~kJ} / \mathrm{kg}-305.22 \mathrm{~kJ} / \mathrm{kg})}{\left(\frac{1}{32 \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{kmol}}\right)(11,711 \mathrm{~kJ} / \mathrm{kmol}-9,325 \mathrm{~kJ} / \mathrm{kmol})} \\
& =23.1 \frac{\mathrm{~kg}}{\min }
\end{aligned}
$$

b. To obtain the mole fractions of the dry air and oxygen in the exiting mixture, first convert the mass flow rates to molar flow rates using the respective molecular weights

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \dot{n}_{\mathrm{a}}=\frac{\dot{m}_{\mathrm{a}}}{M_{\mathrm{a}}}=\frac{114.29 \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{min}}{28.97 \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{kmol}}=3.95 \mathrm{kmol} / \mathrm{min} \\
& \dot{n}_{\mathrm{o}}=\frac{\dot{m}_{\mathrm{o}}}{M_{\mathrm{o}}}=\frac{23.1 \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{min}}{32 \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{kmol}}=0.72 \mathrm{kmol} / \mathrm{min}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\dot{n}$ denotes molar flow rate. The molar flow rate of the mixture $\dot{n}$ is the sum

$$
\dot{n}=\dot{n}_{\mathrm{a}}+\dot{n}_{\mathrm{o}}=3.95+0.72=4.67 \mathrm{kmol} / \mathrm{min}
$$

The mole fractions of the air and oxygen in the exiting mixture are, respectively,
(1) $y_{\mathrm{a}}=\frac{\dot{n}_{\mathrm{a}}}{\dot{n}}=\frac{3.95}{4.67}=0.846 \quad$ and $\quad y_{\mathrm{o}}=\frac{\dot{n}_{\mathrm{o}}}{\dot{n}}=\frac{0.72}{4.67}=0.154$
c. For the control volume at steady state, the entropy rate balance reduces to

$$
\begin{aligned}
0= & \dot{m}_{\mathrm{a}} s_{\mathrm{a}}\left(T_{3}, p_{1}\right)+\dot{m}_{\mathrm{o}} s_{\mathrm{o}}\left(T_{2}, p_{2}\right)-\left[\dot{m}_{\mathrm{a}} s_{\mathrm{a}}\left(T_{3}, y_{\mathrm{a}} p_{3}\right)\right. \\
& \left.+\dot{m}_{\mathrm{o}} s_{\mathrm{o}}\left(T_{3}, y_{\mathrm{o}} p_{3}\right)\right]+\dot{\sigma}
\end{aligned}
$$

The specific entropy of each component in the exiting ideal gas mixture is evaluated at its partial pressure in the mixture and at the mixture temperature. Solving for $\dot{\sigma}$

$$
\dot{\sigma}=\dot{m}_{\mathrm{a}}\left[s_{\mathrm{a}}\left(T_{3}, y_{\mathrm{a}} p_{3}\right)-s_{\mathrm{a}}\left(T_{1}, p_{1}\right)\right]+\dot{m}_{\mathrm{o}}\left[s_{\mathrm{o}}\left(T_{3}, y_{\mathrm{o}} p_{3}\right)-s_{\mathrm{o}}\left(T_{2}, p_{2}\right)\right]
$$

Since $p_{1}=p_{3}$, the specific entropy change of the dry air is

$$
\begin{aligned}
s_{\mathrm{a}}\left(T_{3}, y_{\mathrm{a}} p_{3}\right)-s_{\mathrm{a}}\left(T_{1}, p_{1}\right) & =s_{\mathrm{a}}^{\circ}\left(T_{3}\right)-s_{\mathrm{a}}^{\circ}\left(T_{1}\right)-\frac{\widetilde{R}}{M_{\mathrm{a}}} \ln \frac{y_{\mathrm{a}} p_{3}}{p_{1}} \\
& =s_{\mathrm{a}}^{\circ}\left(T_{3}\right)-s_{\mathrm{a}}^{\circ}\left(T_{1}\right)-\frac{\widetilde{R}}{M_{\mathrm{a}}} \ln y_{\mathrm{a}}
\end{aligned}
$$

The $s_{\mathrm{a}}^{\circ}$ terms are evaluated from Table A-22. Similarly, since $p_{2}=p_{3}$, the specific entropy change of the oxygen is

$$
s_{\mathrm{o}}\left(T_{3}, y_{\mathrm{o}} p_{3}\right)-s_{\mathrm{o}}\left(T_{2}, p_{2}\right)=\frac{1}{M_{\mathrm{o}}}\left[\widetilde{s}_{\mathrm{o}}^{\circ}\left(T_{3}\right)-\widetilde{s}_{\mathrm{o}}^{\circ}\left(T_{2}\right)-\widetilde{R} \ln y_{\mathrm{o}}\right]
$$

The $\widetilde{s}_{\mathrm{o}}^{\circ}$ terms are evaluated from Table A-23. Note the use of the molecular weights $M_{\mathrm{a}}$ and $M_{\mathrm{o}}$ in the last two equations to obtain the respective entropy changes on a mass basis.

The expression for the rate of entropy production becomes

$$
\begin{aligned}
\dot{\sigma}= & \dot{m}_{\mathrm{a}}\left[s_{\mathrm{a}}^{\circ}\left(T_{3}\right)-s_{\mathrm{a}}^{\circ}\left(T_{1}\right)-\frac{\widetilde{R}}{M_{\mathrm{a}}} \ln y_{\mathrm{a}}\right] \\
& +\frac{\dot{m}_{\mathrm{o}}}{M_{\mathrm{o}}}\left[\widetilde{s}_{\mathrm{o}}^{\circ}\left(T_{3}\right)-\widetilde{s}_{\mathrm{o}}^{\circ}\left(T_{2}\right)-\widetilde{R} \ln y_{\mathrm{o}}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Substituting values

$$
\begin{aligned}
\dot{\sigma}= & \left(114.29 \frac{\mathrm{~kg}}{\min }\right)\left[1.7669 \frac{\mathrm{~kJ}}{\mathrm{~kg} \cdot \mathrm{~K}}-1.71865 \frac{\mathrm{~kJ}}{\mathrm{~kg} \cdot \mathrm{~K}}\right. \\
& -\left(\frac{8.314}{28.97} \frac{\mathrm{~kJ}}{\mathrm{~kg} \cdot \mathrm{~K}}\right) \ln 0.846] \\
& +\left(\frac{23.1 \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{min}}{32 \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{kmol}}\right)\left[207.112 \frac{\mathrm{~kJ}}{\mathrm{kmol} \cdot \mathrm{~K}}-213.765 \frac{\mathrm{~kJ}}{\mathrm{kmol} \cdot \mathrm{~K}}\right. \\
& \left.-\left(8.314 \frac{\mathrm{~kJ}}{\mathrm{kmol} \cdot \mathrm{~K}}\right) \ln 0.154\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

(2) $=17.42 \frac{\mathrm{~kJ}}{\mathrm{~K} \cdot \min }}$
(1) This calculation is based on dry air modeled as a pure component (assumption 5). However, since $\mathrm{O}_{2}$ is a component of dry air (Table 12.1), the actual mole fraction of $\mathrm{O}_{2}$ in the exiting mixture is greater than given here.
(2) Entropy is produced when different gases, initially at different temperatures, are allowed to mix.

# Psychrometric Applications 

The remainder of this chapter is concerned with the study of systems involving mixtures of dry air and water vapor. A condensed water phase also may be present. Knowledge of the behavior of such systems is essential for the analysis and design of air-conditioning devices, cooling towers, and industrial processes requiring close control of the vapor content in air. The study of systems involving dry air and water is known as psychrometrics.

### 12.5 Introducing Psychrometric Principles

The object of the present section is to introduce some important definitions and principles used in the study of systems involving dry air and water.

### 12.5.1 Moist Air

moist air


F16_12.3 Mixture of dry air and water vapor.

The term moist air refers to a mixture of dry air and water vapor in which the dry air is treated as if it were a pure component. As can be verified by reference to appropriate property data, the overall mixture and each mixture component behave as ideal gases at the states under present consideration. Accordingly, for the applications to be considered, the ideal gas mixture concepts introduced previously apply directly.

## TAKE NOTE...

Moist air is a binary mixture of dry air and water vapor, and the property relations of Table 12.2 apply.

In particular, the Dalton model and the relations provided in Table 12.2 are applicable to moist air mixtures. Simply by identifying gas 1 with dry air, denoted by the subscript a, and gas 2 with water vapor, denoted by the subscript v , the table gives a useful set of moist air property relations. Referring to Fig. 12.3, let's verify this point by obtaining a sampling of moist air relations and relating them to entries in Table 12.2.

Shown in Fig. 12.3-a special case of Fig. 12.1-is a closed system consisting of moist air occupying a volume $V$ at mixture pressure $p$ and mixture temperature $T$. The overall mixture is assumed to obey the ideal gas equation of state. Thus,

$$
p=\frac{n \bar{R} T}{V}=\frac{m(\bar{R} / M) T}{V}
$$

where $n, m$, and $M$ denote the moles, mass, and molecular weight of the mixture, respectively, and $n=m / M$.
Each mixture component is considered to act as if it existed alone in the volume $V$ at the mixture temperature $T$ while exerting a part of the pressure. The mixture pressure is the sum of the partial pressures of the dry air and the water vapor: $p=p_{\mathrm{a}}+p_{\mathrm{v}}$. That is, the Dalton model applies.

Using the ideal gas equation of state, the partial pressures $p_{\mathrm{a}}$ and $p_{\mathrm{v}}$ of the dry air and water vapor are, respectively,

$$
p_{\mathrm{a}}=\frac{n_{\mathrm{a}} \widetilde{R} T}{V}=\frac{m_{\mathrm{a}}\left(\widetilde{R} / M_{\mathrm{a}}\right) T}{V}, \quad p_{\mathrm{v}}=\frac{n_{\mathrm{v}} \widetilde{R} T}{V}=\frac{m_{\mathrm{v}}\left(\widetilde{R} / M_{\mathrm{v}}\right) T}{V}
$$

where $n_{\mathrm{a}}$ and $n_{\mathrm{v}}$ denote the moles of dry air and water vapor, respectively; $m_{\mathrm{a}}, m_{\mathrm{v}}, M_{\mathrm{a}}$, and $M_{\mathrm{v}}$ are the respective masses and molecular weights. The amount of water vapor present is normally much less than the amount of dry air. Accordingly, the values of $n_{\mathrm{v}}, m_{\mathrm{v}}$, and $p_{\mathrm{v}}$ are small relative to the corresponding values of $n_{\mathrm{a}}, m_{\mathrm{a}}$, and $p_{\mathrm{a}}$.

Forming ratios with Eqs. 12.40 and 12.41a, we get the following alternative expressions for $p_{\mathrm{a}}$ and $p_{\mathrm{v}}$

$$
p_{\mathrm{a}}=y_{\mathrm{a}} p, \quad p_{\mathrm{v}}=y_{\mathrm{v}} p
$$

where $y_{\mathrm{a}}$ and $y_{\mathrm{v}}$ are the mole fractions of the dry air and water vapor, respectively. These moist air expressions conform to Eqs. (c) in Table 12.2.

A typical state of water vapor in moist air is shown in Fig. 12.4. At this state, fixed by the partial pressure $p_{\mathrm{v}}$ and the mixture temperature $T$, the vapor is superheated. When the partial pressure of the water vapor corresponds to the saturation pressure of water at the mixture temperature, $p_{\mathrm{g}}$ of Fig. 12.4, the mixture is said to be saturated. Saturated air is a mixture of dry air and saturated water vapor. The amount of water vapor in moist air varies from zero in dry air to a maximum, depending on the pressure and temperature, when the mixture is saturated.

### 12.5.2 Humidity Ratio, Relative Humidity, Mixture Enthalpy, and Mixture Entropy

A given moist air sample can be described in a number of ways. The mixture can be described in terms of the moles of dry air and water vapor present or in terms of the respective mole fractions. Alternatively, the mass of dry air and water vapor, or the respective mass fractions, can be specified. The composition also can be indicated by means of the humidity ratio $\omega$, defined as the ratio of the mass of the water vapor to the mass of dry air

$$
\omega=\frac{m_{\mathrm{v}}}{m_{\mathrm{a}}}
$$



FIG. 12.4 $T-v$ diagram for water vapor in an air-water mixture.

Saturated air
humidity ratio
relative humidity


Sensing element
mixture enthalpy

The humidity ratio is sometimes referred to as the specific humidity.
The humidity ratio can be expressed in terms of partial pressures and molecular weights by solving Eqs. 12.41a for $m_{\mathrm{a}}$ and $m_{\mathrm{v}}$, respectively, and substituting the resulting expressions into Eq. 12.42 to obtain

$$
\omega=\frac{m_{\mathrm{v}}}{m_{\mathrm{a}}}=\frac{M_{\mathrm{v}} p_{\mathrm{v}} V / \widetilde{R} T}{M_{\mathrm{a}} p_{\mathrm{a}} V / \widetilde{R} T}=\frac{M_{\mathrm{v}} p_{\mathrm{v}}}{M_{\mathrm{a}} p_{\mathrm{a}}}
$$

Introducing $p_{\mathrm{a}}=p-p_{\mathrm{v}}$ and noting that the ratio of the molecular weight of water to that of dry air, $M_{\mathrm{v}} / M_{\mathrm{a}}$, is approximately 0.622 , this expression can be written as

$$
\omega=0.622 \frac{p_{\mathrm{v}}}{p-p_{\mathrm{v}}}
$$

Moist air also can be described in terms of the relative humidity $\phi$, defined as the ratio of the mole fraction of water vapor $y_{\mathrm{v}}$ in a given moist air sample to the mole fraction $y_{\mathrm{v}, \text { sat }}$ in a saturated moist air sample at the same mixture temperature and pressure:

$$
\phi=\frac{y_{\mathrm{v}}}{y_{\mathrm{v}, \text { sat }}})_{T, p}
$$

Since $p_{\mathrm{v}}=y_{\mathrm{v}} p$ and $p_{\mathrm{g}}=y_{\mathrm{v}, \text { sat }} p$, the relative humidity can be expressed as

$$
\phi=\frac{p_{\mathrm{v}}}{p_{\mathrm{g}}}_{T, p}
$$

The pressures in this expression for the relative humidity are labeled on Fig. 12.4.
The humidity ratio and relative humidity can be measured. For laboratory measurements of humidity ratio, a hygrometer can be used in which a moist air sample is exposed to suitable chemicals until the moisture present is absorbed. The amount of water vapor is determined by weighing the chemicals. Continuous recording of the relative humidity can be accomplished by means of transducers consisting of resistance- or capacitance-type sensors whose electrical characteristics change with relative humidity.

Evaluating $H, U$, and $S$ for Moist Air The values of $H, U$, and $S$ for moist air modeled as an ideal gas mixture can be found by adding the contribution of each component at the condition at which the component exists in the mixture. For example, the enthalpy $H$ of a given moist air sample is

$$
H=H_{\mathrm{a}}+H_{\mathrm{v}}=m_{\mathrm{a}} h_{\mathrm{a}}+m_{\mathrm{v}} h_{\mathrm{v}}
$$

This moist air expression conforms to Eq. (d) in Table 12.2.
Dividing by $m_{\mathrm{a}}$ and introducing the humidity ratio gives the mixture enthalpy per unit mass of dry air

$$
\frac{H}{m_{\mathrm{a}}}=h_{\mathrm{a}}+\frac{m_{\mathrm{v}}}{m_{\mathrm{a}}} h_{\mathrm{v}}=h_{\mathrm{a}}+\omega h_{\mathrm{v}}
$$

The enthalpies of the dry air and water vapor appearing in Eq. 12.46 are evaluated at the mixture temperature. An approach similar to that for enthalpy also applies to the evaluation of the internal energy of moist air.

Reference to steam table data or a Mollier diagram for water shows that the enthalpy of superheated water vapor at low vapor pressures is very closely given by the saturated vapor value corresponding to the given temperature. Hence, the enthalpy of the water vapor $h_{\mathrm{v}}$ in Eq. 12.46 can be taken as $h_{\mathrm{g}}$ at the mixture temperature. That is,

$$
h_{\mathrm{v}}=h_{\mathrm{g}}(T)
$$Equation 12.47 is used in the remainder of the chapter. Enthalpy data for water vapor as an ideal gas from Table A-23 are not used for $h_{\mathrm{v}}$ because the enthalpy datum of the ideal gas tables differs from that of the steam tables. These different datums can lead to error when studying systems that contain both water vapor and a liquid or solid phase of water. The enthalpy of dry air, $h_{\mathrm{a}}$, can be obtained from the appropriate ideal gas table, Table A-22 or Table A-22E, however, because air is a gas at all states under present consideration and is closely modeled as an ideal gas at these states.

In accord with Eq. (h) in Table 12.2, the moist air mixture entropy has two contributions: water vapor and dry air. The contribution of each component is determined at the mixture temperature and the partial pressure of the component in the mixture. Using Eq. 6.18 and referring to Fig. 12.4 for the states, the specific entropy of the water vapor is given by $s_{\mathrm{v}}\left(T, p_{\mathrm{v}}\right)=s_{\mathrm{g}}(T)-R \ln p_{\mathrm{v}} / p_{\mathrm{g}}$, where $s_{\mathrm{g}}$ is the specific entropy of saturated vapor at temperature $T$. Observe that the ratio of pressures, $p_{\mathrm{v}} / p_{\mathrm{g}}$, can be replaced by the relative humidity $\phi$, giving an alternative expression.

Using Computer Software Property functions for moist air are listed under the Properties menu of Interactive Thermodynamics: IT. Functions are included for humidity ratio, relative humidity, specific enthalpy and entropy as well as other psychrometric properties introduced later. The methods used for evaluating these functions correspond to the methods discussed in this chapter, and the values returned by the computer software agree closely with those obtained by hand calculations with table data. The use of $I T$ for psychrometric evaluations is illustrated in examples later in the chapter.

### 12.5.3 Modeling Moist Air in Equilibrium with Liquid Water

Thus far, our study of psychrometrics has been conducted as an application of the ideal gas mixture principles introduced in the first part of this chapter. However, many systems of interest are composed of a mixture of dry air and water vapor in contact with a liquid (or solid) water phase. To study these systems requires additional considerations.

Shown in Fig. 12.5 is a vessel containing liquid water, above which is a mixture of water vapor and dry air. If no interactions with the surroundings are allowed, liquid will evaporate until eventually the gas phase becomes saturated and the system attains an equilibrium state. For many engineering applications, systems consisting of moist air in equilibrium with a liquid water phase can be described simply and accurately with the following idealizations:

- The dry air and water vapor behave as independent ideal gases.
- The equilibrium between the liquid phase and the water vapor is not significantly disturbed by the presence of the air.


FIG. 12.5 System consisting of moist air in contact with liquid water.
- The partial pressure of the water vapor equals the saturation pressure of water corresponding to the temperature of the mixture: $p_{\mathrm{v}}=p_{\mathrm{g}}(T)$.

Similar considerations apply for systems consisting of moist air in equilibrium with a solid water phase. The presence of the air actually alters the partial pressure of the vapor from the saturation pressure by a small amount whose magnitude is calculated in Sec. 14.6.

# 12.5.4 Evaluating the Dew Point Temperature 

A significant aspect of the behavior of moist air is that partial condensation of the water vapor can occur when the temperature is reduced. This type of phenomenon is commonly encountered in the condensation of vapor on windowpanes and on pipes carrying cold water. The formation of dew on grass is another familiar example.

To study such condensation, consider a closed system consisting of a sample of moist air that is cooled at constant pressure, as shown in Fig. 12.6. The property diagram given on this figure locates states of the water vapor. Initially, the water vapor is superheated at state 1 . In the first part of the cooling process, both the system pressure and the composition of the moist air remain constant. Accordingly, since $p_{\mathrm{v}}=y_{\mathrm{v}} p$, the partial pressure of the water vapor remains constant, and the water vapor cools at constant $p_{\mathrm{v}}$ from state 1 to state d , called the dew point. The saturation temperature corresponding to $p_{\mathrm{v}}$ is called the dew point temperature. This temperature is labeled on Fig. 12.6.

In the next part of the cooling process, the system cools below the dew point temperature and some of the water vapor initially present condenses. At the final state, the system consists of a gas phase of dry air and water vapor in equilibrium with a liquid water phase. In accord with the discussion of Sec. 12.5.3, the vapor that remains is saturated vapor at the final temperature, state 2 of Fig. 12.6, with a partial pressure equal to the saturation pressure $p_{\mathrm{g} 2}$ corresponding to this temperature. The condensate is saturated liquid at the final temperature: state 3 of Fig. 12.6.

Referring again to Fig. 12.6, note that the partial pressure of the water vapor at the final state, $p_{\mathrm{g} 2}$, is less than the initial value, $p_{\mathrm{v} 1}$. Owing to condensation, the partial pressure decreases because the amount of water vapor present at the final state is less than at the initial state. Since the amount of dry air is unchanged, the mole fraction of water vapor in the moist air also decreases.

In the next two examples, we illustrate the use of psychrometric properties introduced thus far. The examples consider, respectively, cooling moist air at constant pressure and at constant volume.


FIG. 12.6 States of water for moist air cooled at constant mixture pressure.
# EXAMPLE 12.7 | Cooling Moist Air at Constant Pressure 

A 1-lb sample of moist air initially at $70^{\circ} \mathrm{F}, 14.7 \mathrm{lbf} / \mathrm{in} .^{2}$, and $70 \%$ relative humidity is cooled to $40^{\circ} \mathrm{F}$ while keeping the pressure constant. Determine (a) the initial humidity ratio, (b) the dew point temperature, in ${ }^{\circ} \mathrm{F}$, and (c) the amount of water vapor that condenses, in lb .

## Solution

Known A 1-lb sample of moist air is cooled at a constant mixture pressure of $14.7 \mathrm{lbf} / \mathrm{in} .^{2}$ from 70 to $40^{\circ} \mathrm{F}$. The initial relative humidity is $70 \%$.

Find Determine the initial humidity ratio, the dew point temperature, in ${ }^{\circ} \mathrm{F}$, and the amount of water vapor that condenses, in lb .

## Schematic and Given Data:



FIG. E12.7

## Engineering Model

1. The 1-lb sample of moist air is taken as the closed system. The system pressure remains constant at $14.7 \mathrm{lbf} / \mathrm{in} .^{2}$
2. The gas phase can be treated as an ideal gas mixture. The Dalton model applies: Each mixture component acts as an ideal gas existing alone in the volume occupied by the gas phase at the mixture temperature.
3. When a liquid water phase is present, the water vapor exists as a saturated vapor at the system temperature. The liquid present is a saturated liquid at the system temperature.

## Analysis

a. The initial humidity ratio can be evaluated from Eq. 12.43. This requires the partial pressure of the water vapor, $p_{\mathrm{v} 1}$, which can be found from the given relative humidity and $p_{\mathrm{g}}$ from Table A-2E at $70^{\circ} \mathrm{F}$ as follows

$$
p_{\mathrm{v} 1}=\phi p_{\mathrm{g}}=(0.7)\left(0.3632 \frac{\mathrm{lbf}}{\mathrm{in} .^{2}}\right)=0.2542 \frac{\mathrm{lbf}}{\mathrm{in} .^{2}}
$$

Inserting values in Eq. 12.43

$$
\omega_{1}=0.622\left(\frac{0.2542}{14.7-0.2542}\right)=0.011 \frac{\mathrm{lb}(\text { vapor })}{\mathrm{lb}(\text { dry air })}
$$

b. The dew point temperature is the saturation temperature corresponding to the partial pressure, $p_{\mathrm{v} 1}$. Interpolation in Table A-2E gives $T=60^{\circ} \mathrm{F}$. The dew point temperature is labeled on the accompanying property diagram.
c. The amount of condensate, $m_{\mathrm{w}}$, equals the difference between the initial amount of water vapor in the sample, $m_{\mathrm{v} 1}$, and the final amount of water vapor, $m_{\mathrm{v} 2}$. That is,

$$
m_{\mathrm{w}}=m_{\mathrm{v} 1}-m_{\mathrm{v} 2}
$$

To evaluate $m_{\mathrm{v} 1}$, note that the system initially consists of 1 lb of dry air and water vapor, so $1 \mathrm{lb}=m_{\mathrm{a}}+m_{\mathrm{v} 1}$, where $m_{\mathrm{a}}$ is the mass of dry air present in the sample. Since $\omega_{1}=m_{\mathrm{v} 1} / m_{\mathrm{a}}, m_{\mathrm{a}}=m_{\mathrm{v} 1} / \omega_{1}$. With this we get

$$
1 \mathrm{lb}=\frac{m_{\mathrm{v} 1}}{\omega_{1}}+m_{\mathrm{v} 1}=m_{\mathrm{v} 1}\left(\frac{1}{\omega_{1}}+1\right)
$$

Solving for $m_{\mathrm{v} 1}$

$$
m_{\mathrm{v} 1}=\frac{1 \mathrm{lb}}{\left(1 / \omega_{1}\right)+1}
$$

Inserting the value of $\omega_{1}$ determined in part (a)

$$
m_{\mathrm{v} 1}=\frac{1 \mathrm{lb}}{(1 / 0.011)+1}=0.0109 \mathrm{lb}(\text { vapor })
$$

(3) The mass of dry air present is then $m_{\mathrm{a}}=1-0.0109=0.9891 \mathrm{lb}$ (dry air).

Next, let us evaluate $m_{\mathrm{v} 2}$. With assumption 3, the partial pressure of the water vapor remaining in the system at the final state is the saturation pressure corresponding to $40^{\circ} \mathrm{F}: p_{\mathrm{g}}=0.1217 \mathrm{lbf} / \mathrm{in} .{ }^{2}$ Accordingly, the humidity ratio after cooling is found from Eq. 12.43 as

$$
\omega_{2}=0.622\left(\frac{0.1217}{14.7-0.1217}\right)=0.0052 \frac{\mathrm{lb}(\text { vapor })}{\mathrm{lb}(\text { dry air })}
$$

The mass of the water vapor present at the final state is then

$$
m_{\mathrm{v} 2}=\omega_{2} m_{\mathrm{a}}=(0.0052)(0.9891)=0.0051 \mathrm{lb}(\text { vapor })
$$

Finally, the amount of water vapor that condenses is

$$
m_{\mathrm{w}}=m_{\mathrm{v} 1}-m_{\mathrm{v} 2}=0.0109-0.0051=0.0058 \mathrm{lb}(\text { condensate })
$$

(4) The amount of water vapor present in a typical moist air mixture is considerably less than the amount of dry air present.

Determine the quality of the two-phase liquid-vapor mixture and the relative humidity of the gas phase at the final state. Ans. $47 \%, 100 \%$.
An air-water vapor mixture is contained in a rigid, closed vessel with a volume of $35 \mathrm{~m}^{3}$ at $1.5 \mathrm{bar}, 120^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, and $\phi=10 \%$. The mixture is cooled at constant volume until its temperature is reduced to $22^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. Determine (a) the dew point temperature corresponding to the initial state, in ${ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, (b) the temperature at which condensation actually begins, in ${ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, and (c) the amount of water condensed, in kg .

## Solution

Known A rigid, closed tank with a volume of $35 \mathrm{~m}^{3}$ containing moist air initially at $1.5 \mathrm{bar}, 120^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, and $\phi=10 \%$ is cooled to $22^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$.

Find Determine the dew point temperature at the initial state, in ${ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, the temperature at which condensation actually begins, in ${ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, and the amount of water condensed, in kg .

## Schematic and Given Data:



## FIG. 8.12.8

## Engineering Model

1. The contents of the tank are taken as a closed system. The system volume remains constant.
2. The gas phase can be treated as an ideal gas mixture. The Dalton model applies: Each mixture component acts as an ideal gas existing alone in the volume occupied by the gas phase at the mixture temperature.
3. When a liquid water phase is present, the water vapor exists as a saturated vapor at the system temperature. The liquid is a saturated liquid at the system temperature.

## Analysis

a. The dew point temperature at the initial state is the saturation temperature corresponding to the partial pressure $p_{\mathrm{v} 1}$.

With the given relative humidity and the saturation pressure at $120^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ from Table A-2

$$
p_{\mathrm{v} 1}=\phi_{\mathrm{i}} p_{\mathrm{gl}}=(0.10)(1.985)=0.1985 \mathrm{bar}
$$

Interpolating in Table A-2 gives the dew point temperature as $60^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, which is the temperature condensation would begin if the moist air were cooled at constant pressure.
b. Whether the water exists as a vapor only, or as liquid and vapor, it occupies the full volume, which remains constant. Accordingly, since the total mass of the water present is also constant, the water undergoes the constant specific volume process illustrated on the accompanying $T-v$ diagram. In the process from state 1 to state $1^{\prime}$, the water exists as a vapor only. For the process from state $1^{\prime}$ to state 2 , the water exists as a two-phase liquid-vapor mixture. Note that pressure does not remain constant during the cooling process from state 1 to state 2 .

State $1^{\prime}$ on the $T-v$ diagram denotes the state where the water vapor first becomes saturated. The saturation temperature at this state is denoted as $T^{\prime}$. Cooling to a temperature less than $T^{\prime}$ results in condensation of some of the water vapor present. Since state $1^{\prime}$ is a saturated vapor state, the temperature $T^{\prime}$ can be found by interpolating in Table A-2 with the specific volume of the water at this state. The specific volume of the vapor at state $1^{\prime}$ equals the specific volume of the vapor at state 1 , which can be evaluated from the ideal gas equation

$$
\begin{aligned}
v_{\mathrm{v} 1} & =\frac{\left(\bar{R} / M_{v}\right) T_{1}}{p_{\mathrm{v} 1}}=\left(\begin{array}{ll}
8314 & \mathrm{~N} \cdot \mathrm{~m} \\
18 & \mathrm{~kg} \cdot \mathrm{~K}
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{c}
393 \mathrm{~K} \\
0.1985 \times 10^{5} \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}^{2}
\end{array}\right) \\
& =9.145 \frac{\mathrm{~m}^{3}}{\mathrm{~kg}}
\end{aligned}
$$

(4) Interpolation in Table A-2 with $v_{v 1}=v_{g}$ gives $T^{\prime}=56^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. This is the temperature at which condensation begins.
c. The amount of condensate equals the difference between the initial and final amounts of water vapor present. The mass of the water vapor present initially is

$$
m_{\mathrm{v} 1}=\frac{V}{v_{\mathrm{v} 1}}=\frac{35 \mathrm{~m}^{3}}{9.145 \mathrm{~m}^{3} / \mathrm{kg}}=3.827 \mathrm{~kg}
$$

The mass of water vapor present finally can be determined from the quality. At the final state, the water forms a two-phase liquid-vapor mixture having a specific volume of $9.145 \mathrm{~m}^{3} / \mathrm{kg}$. Using this specific volume value, the quality $x_{2}$ of the liquidvapor mixture can be found as

$$
x_{2}=\frac{v_{\mathrm{v} 2}-v_{\mathrm{f} 2}}{v_{\mathrm{g} 2}-v_{\mathrm{f} 2}}=\frac{9.145-1.0022 \times 10^{-3}}{51.447-1.0022 \times 10^{-3}}=0.178
$$

where $v_{\mathrm{f} 2}$ and $v_{\mathrm{g} 2}$ are the saturated liquid and saturated vapor specific volumes at $T_{2}=22^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, respectively.

Using the quality together with the known total amount of water present, 3.827 kg , the mass of the water vapor contained in the system at the final state is

$$
m_{\mathrm{v} 2}=(0.178)(3.827)=0.681 \mathrm{~kg}
$$

The mass of the condensate, $m_{\mathrm{w} 2}$, is then

$$
m_{\mathrm{w} 2}=m_{\mathrm{v} 1}-m_{\mathrm{v} 2}=3.827-0.681=3.146 \mathrm{~kg}
$$
(4) When a moist air mixture is cooled at constant mixture volume, the temperature at which condensation begins is not the dew point temperature corresponding to the initial state. In this case, condensation begins at $56^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, but the dew point temperature at the initial state, determined in part (a), is $60^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$.

# EXAMPLE 12.9 | Evaluating Heat Transfer for Moist Air Cooling at Constant Volume 

An air-water vapor mixture is contained in a rigid, closed vessel with a volume of $35 \mathrm{~m}^{3}$ at $1.5 \mathrm{bar}, 120^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, and $\phi=10 \%$. The mixture is cooled until its temperature is reduced to $22^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. Determine the heat transfer during the process, in kJ .

## Solution

Known A rigid, closed tank with a volume of $35 \mathrm{~m}^{3}$ containing moist air initially at $1.5 \mathrm{bar}, 120^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, and $\phi=10 \%$ is cooled to $22^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$.

Find Determine the heat transfer for the process, in kJ.
Schematic and Given Data: See the figure for Example 12.8.

## Engineering Model

1. The contents of the tank are taken as a closed system. The system volume remains constant.
2. The gas phase can be treated as an ideal gas mixture. The Dalton model applies: Each component acts as an ideal gas existing alone in the volume occupied by the gas phase at the mixture temperature.
3. When a liquid water phase is present, the water vapor exists as a saturated vapor and the liquid is a saturated liquid, each at the system temperature.
4. There is no work during the cooling process and no change in kinetic or potential energy.

Analysis Reduction of the closed system energy balance using assumption 4 results in

$$
\Delta U=Q-\psi^{0}
$$

or

$$
Q=U_{2}-U_{1}
$$

where

$$
U_{1}=m_{\mathrm{a}} u_{\mathrm{a} 1}+m_{\mathrm{v} 1} u_{\mathrm{v} 1}=m_{\mathrm{a}} u_{\mathrm{a} 1}+m_{\mathrm{v} 1} u_{\mathrm{g} 1}
$$

and

$$
U_{2}=m_{\mathrm{a}} u_{\mathrm{a} 2}+m_{\mathrm{v} 2} u_{\mathrm{v} 2}+m_{\mathrm{w} 2} u_{\mathrm{w} 2}=m_{\mathrm{a}} u_{\mathrm{a} 2}+m_{\mathrm{v} 2} u_{\mathrm{g} 2}+m_{\mathrm{w} 2} u_{\mathrm{f} 2}
$$

In these equations, the subscripts a, v, and w denote, respectively, dry air, water vapor, and liquid water. The specific internal energy of the water vapor at the initial state can be approximated as the saturated vapor value at $T_{1}$. At the final state, the water vapor is assumed to exist as a saturated vapor, so its specific internal energy is $u_{\mathrm{g}}$ at $T_{2}$. The liquid water at the final state is saturated, so its specific internal energy is $u_{\mathrm{f}}$ at $T_{2}$.

Collecting the last three equations

$$
Q=m_{\mathrm{a}}\left(u_{\mathrm{a} 2}-u_{\mathrm{a} 1}\right)+m_{\mathrm{v} 2} u_{\mathrm{g} 2}+m_{\mathrm{w} 2} u_{\mathrm{f} 2}-m_{\mathrm{v} 1} u_{\mathrm{g} 1}
$$

The mass of dry air, $m_{\mathrm{a}}$, can be found using the ideal gas equation of state together with the partial pressure of the dry air at the initial state obtained using $p_{\mathrm{v} 1}=0.1985$ bar from the solution to Example 12.8 as follows:

$$
\begin{aligned}
m_{\mathrm{a}} & =\frac{p_{\mathrm{a} 1} V}{\left(\bar{R} / M_{\mathrm{a}}\right) T_{1}}=\frac{\left[(1.5-0.1985) \times 10^{5} \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}^{2}\right]\left(35 \mathrm{~m}^{3}\right)}{(8314 / 28.97 \mathrm{~N} \cdot \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{kg} \cdot \mathrm{~K})(393 \mathrm{~K})} \\
& =40.389 \mathrm{~kg}
\end{aligned}
$$

Then, evaluating internal energies of dry air and water from Tables A-22 and A-2, respectively,

$$
\begin{aligned}
Q= & 40.389(210.49-281.1)+0.681(2405.7)+3.146(92.32) \\
& -3.827(2529.3) \\
= & -2851.87+1638.28+290.44-9679.63=-10,603 \mathrm{~kJ}
\end{aligned}
$$

The values for $m_{\mathrm{v} 1}, m_{\mathrm{v} 2}$, and $m_{\mathrm{w} 2}$ are from the solution to Example 12.8 .
(5) The first underlined term in this equation for $Q$ is evaluated with specific internal energies from the ideal gas table for air, Table A-22. Steam table data are used to evaluate the second underlined term. The different datums for internal energy underlying these tables cancel because each of these two terms
involves internal energy differences. Since the specific heat $c_{\text {va }}$ for dry air varies only slightly over the interval from 120 to $22^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ (Table A-20), the specific internal energy change of the dry air could be evaluated alternatively using a constant $c_{\text {va }}$ value. See the Quick Quiz that follows.

# 12.5.5 Evaluating Humidity Ratio Using the Adiabatic-Saturation Temperature 

The humidity ratio $\omega$ of an air-water vapor mixture can be determined, in principle, knowing the values of three mixture properties: the pressure $p$, the temperature $T$, and the adiabatic-
adiabatic-saturation temperature $T_{\mathrm{as}}$ introduced in this section. The relationship among these mixture properties is obtained by applying conservation of mass and conservation of energy to an adiabatic saturator (see box).

Equations 12.48 and 12.49 give the humidity ratio $\omega$ in terms of the adiabatic-saturation temperature and other quantities:

$$
\omega=\frac{h_{\mathrm{a}}\left(T_{\mathrm{as}}\right)-h_{\mathrm{a}}(T)+\omega^{\prime}\left[h_{\mathrm{g}}\left(T_{\mathrm{as}}\right)-h_{\mathrm{f}}\left(T_{\mathrm{as}}\right)\right]}{h_{\mathrm{g}}(T)-h_{\mathrm{f}}\left(T_{\mathrm{as}}\right)}
$$

where $h_{\mathrm{f}}$ and $h_{\mathrm{g}}$ denote the enthalpies of saturated liquid water and saturated water vapor, respectively, obtained from the steam tables at the indicated temperatures. The enthalpies of the dry air $h_{\mathrm{a}}$ can be obtained from the ideal gas table for air. Alternatively, $h_{\mathrm{a}}\left(T_{\mathrm{as}}\right)-h_{\mathrm{a}}(T)=c_{p \mathrm{a}}\left(T_{\mathrm{as}}-T\right)$, where $c_{p \mathrm{a}}$ is an appropriate constant value for the specific heat of dry air. The humidity ratio $\omega^{\prime}$ appearing in Eq. 12.48 is

$$
\omega^{\prime}=0.622 \frac{p_{\mathrm{g}}\left(T_{\mathrm{as}}\right)}{p-p_{\mathrm{g}}\left(T_{\mathrm{as}}\right)}
$$

where $p_{\mathrm{g}}\left(T_{\mathrm{as}}\right)$ is the saturation pressure at the adiabatic-saturation temperature and $p$ is the mixture pressure.

## Modeling an Adiabatic Saturator

Figure 12.7 shows the schematic and process representations of an adiabatic saturator, which is a two-inlet, single-exit device through which moist air passes. The device is assumed to operate at steady state and without significant heat transfer with its surroundings. An air-water vapor mixture of unknown humidity ratio $\omega$ enters the adiabatic saturator at a known pressure $p$ and temperature $T$. As the mixture passes through the device, it comes into contact with a pool of water. If the entering mixture is not saturated $(\phi<100 \%)$, some of the water would evaporate. The energy required to evaporate the water would come from the moist air, so the mixture temperature would decrease as the air passes through the duct. For a sufficiently long duct, the mixture would be saturated as it exits $(\phi=100 \%)$. Since a saturated mixture would be achieved without heat transfer with the surroundings, the temperature of the exiting mixture is the adiabatic-saturation
temperature. As indicated on Fig. 12.7, a steady flow of makeup water at temperature $T_{\mathrm{as}}$ is added at the same rate at which water is evaporated. The pressure of the mixture is assumed to remain constant as it passes through the device.

Equation 12.48 giving the humidity ratio $\omega$ of the entering moist air in terms of $p, T$, and $T_{\mathrm{as}}$ can be obtained by applying conservation of mass and conservation of energy to the adiabatic saturator, as follows:

At steady state, the mass flow rate of the dry air entering the device, $\dot{m}_{\mathrm{s}}$, must equal the mass flow rate of the dry air exiting. The mass flow rate of the makeup water is the difference between the exiting and entering vapor flow rates denoted by $\dot{m}_{\mathrm{v}}$ and $\dot{m}_{\mathrm{v}}^{\prime}$, respectively. These flow rates are labeled on Fig. 12.7a. At steady state, the energy rate balance reduces to
$\left(\dot{m}_{\mathrm{a}} h_{\mathrm{a}}+\dot{m}_{\mathrm{v}} h_{\mathrm{v}}\right)_{\text {moist }}$ air entering $+\left[\left(\dot{m}_{\mathrm{v}}^{\prime}-\dot{m}_{\mathrm{v}}\right) h_{\mathrm{w}}\right]_{\text {makeup }}+\left(\dot{m}_{\mathrm{a}} h_{\mathrm{a}}+\dot{m}_{\mathrm{v}}^{\prime} h_{\mathrm{v}}\right)_{\text {moist air }}$ exiting


FIG. 12.7 Adiabatic saturator. (a) Schematic. (b) Process representation.

Several assumptions underlie this expression: Each of the two moist air streams is modeled as an ideal gas mixture of dry air and water vapor. Heat transfer with the surroundings is assumed to be negligible. There is no work $\dot{W}_{\mathrm{cv}}$, and changes in kinetic and potential energy are ignored.

Dividing by the mass flow rate of the dry air, $\dot{m}_{\mathrm{a}}$, the energy rate balance can be written on the basis of a unit mass of dry air passing through the device as

$$
\left(h_{\mathrm{a}}+\omega h_{\mathrm{g}}\right)_{\substack{\text { moist air } \\ \text { entering }}}+\left[\left(\omega^{\prime}-\omega\right) h_{\mathrm{f}}\right]_{\substack{\text { makeup } \\ \text { water }}}=\left(h_{\mathrm{a}}+\omega^{\prime} h_{\mathrm{g}}\right)_{\substack{\text { moist air } \\ \text { exiting }}}
$$

where $\omega=\dot{m}_{\mathrm{v}} / \dot{m}_{\mathrm{a}}$ and $\omega^{\prime}=\dot{m}_{\mathrm{v}}^{\prime} / \dot{m}_{\mathrm{a}}$.

For the exiting saturated mixture, the partial pressure of the water vapor is the saturation pressure corresponding to the adiabatic-saturation temperature, $p_{\mathrm{g}}\left(T_{\mathrm{as}}\right)$. Accordingly, the humidity ratio $\omega^{\prime}$ can be evaluated knowing $T_{\mathrm{as}}$ and the mixture pressure $p$, as indicated by Eq. 12.49. In writing Eq. 12.50, the specific enthalpy of the entering water vapor has been evaluated as that of saturated water vapor at the temperature of the incoming mixture, in accordance with Eq. 12.47. Since the exiting mixture is saturated, the enthalpy of the water vapor at the exit is given by the saturated vapor value at $T_{\mathrm{as}}$. The enthalpy of the makeup water is evaluated as that of saturated liquid at $T_{\mathrm{as}}$.

When Eq. 12.50 is solved for $\omega$, Eq. 12.48 results. The details of the solution are left as an exercise.

# TAKE NOTE... 

Although derived with reference to the adiabatic saturator in Fig. 12.7, the relationship provided by Eq. 12.48 applies generally to moist air mixtures and is not restricted to this type of system or even to control volumes. The relationship allows the humidity ratio $\omega$ to be determined for any moist air mixture for which the pressure $p$, temperature $T$, and adiabatic-saturation temperature $T_{\mathrm{as}}$ are known.

### 12.6 Psychrometers: Measuring the Wet-Bulb and Dry-Bulb Temperatures

For moist air mixtures in the normal pressure and temperature ranges of psychrometrics, the readily measured wet-bulb temperature is an important parameter.

The wet-bulb temperature is read from a wet-bulb thermometer, which is an ordinary liquid-in-glass thermometer whose bulb is enclosed by a wick moistened with water. The term dry-bulb temperature refers simply to the temperature that would be measured by a thermometer placed in the mixture. Often a wet-bulb thermometer is mounted together with a dry-bulb thermometer to form an instrument called a psychrometer.

The psychrometer of Fig. 12.8a is whirled in the air whose wet- and dry-bulb temperatures are to be determined. This induces air flow over the two thermometers. For the
wet-bulb temperature
dry-bulb temperature
psychrometer


FIG. 12.8 Psychrometers. (a) Sling psychrometer. (b) Aspirating psychrometer.
psychrometer of Fig. 12.8b, the air flow is induced by a battery-operated fan. In each type of psychrometer, if the surrounding air is not saturated, water in the wick of the wet-bulb thermometer evaporates and the temperature of the remaining water falls below the dry-bulb temperature. Eventually a steady-state condition is attained by the wet-bulb thermometer. The wet- and dry-bulb temperatures are then read from the respective thermometers. The wet-bulb temperature depends on the rates of heat and mass transfer between the moistened wick and the air. Since these depend in turn on the geometry of the thermometer, air velocity, supply water temperature, and other factors, the wet-bulb temperature is not a mixture property.

TAKE NOTE...
The humidity ratio for moist air mixtures considered in this book can be calculated by using the wet-bulb temperature in Eqs. 12.48 and 12.49 in place of the adiabatic-saturation temperature.

For moist air mixtures in the normal pressure and temperature ranges of psychrometric applications, the adiabatic-saturation temperature introduced in Sec. 12.5.5 is closely approximated by the wet-bulb temperature. Accordingly, the humidity ratio for any such mixture can be calculated by using the wet-bulb temperature in Eqs. 12.48 and 12.49 in place of the adiabatic-saturation temperature. Close agreement between the adiabatic-saturation and wetbulb temperatures is not generally found for moist air departing from normal psychrometric conditions.

# 12.7 Psychrometric Charts 

Graphical representations of several important properties of moist air are provided by psychrometric charts. The main features of one form of chart are shown in Fig. 12.9. Complete charts in SI and English units are given in Figs. A-9 and A-9E. These charts are constructed for a mixture pressure of 1 atm , but charts for other mixture pressures are also available. When the mixture pressure differs only slightly from 1 atm , Figs. A-9 remain sufficiently accurate for engineering analyses. In this text, such differences are ignored.

Let us consider several features of the psychrometric chart:

- Referring to Fig. 12.9, note that the abscissa gives the dry-bulb temperature and the ordinate provides the humidity ratio. For charts in SI, the temperature is in ${ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and $\omega$
is expressed in kg , or g , of water vapor per kg of dry air. Charts in English units give temperature in ${ }^{\circ} \mathrm{F}$ and $\omega$ in lb , or grains, of water vapor per lb of dry air, where $1 \mathrm{lb}=$ 7000 grains.

- Equation 12.43 shows that for fixed mixture pressure there is a direct correspondence between the partial pressure of the water vapor and the humidity ratio. Accordingly, the vapor pressure also can be shown on the ordinate, as illustrated on Fig. 12.9.
- Curves of constant relative humidity are shown on psychrometric charts. On Fig. 12.9, curves labeled $\phi=100,50$, and $10 \%$ are indicated. Since the dew point is the state where the mixture becomes saturated when cooled at constant vapor pressure, the dew point temperature corresponding to a given moist air state can be determined by following a line of constant $\omega$ (constant $p_{\mathrm{v}}$ ) to the saturation line, $\phi=100 \%$. The dew point temperature and dry-bulb temperature are identical for states on the saturation curve.
- Psychrometric charts also give values of the mixture enthalpy per unit mass of dry air in the mixture: $h_{\mathrm{a}}+\omega h_{\mathrm{v}}$. In Figs. A-9 and A-9E, the mixture enthalpy has units of kJ per kg of dry air and Btu per lb of dry air, respectively. The numerical values provided on these charts are determined relative to the following special reference states and reference values. In Fig. A-9, the enthalpy of the dry air $h_{\mathrm{a}}$ is determined relative to a zero value at $0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, and not 0 K as in Table A-22. Accordingly, in place of Eq. 3.49 used to develop the enthalpy data of Tables A-22, the following expression is employed to evaluate the enthalpy of the dry air for use on the psychrometric chart:

$$
h_{\mathrm{a}}=\int_{273.15 \mathrm{~K}}^{T} c_{p \mathrm{a}} d T=c_{p \mathrm{a}} T\left({ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\right)
$$

where $c_{p a}$ is a constant value for the specific heat $c_{p}$ of dry air and $T\left({ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\right)$ denotes the temperature in ${ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. For the chart in English units, Fig. A-9E, $h_{\mathrm{a}}$ is determined relative to a datum of $0^{\circ} \mathrm{F}$, using $h_{\mathrm{a}}=c_{p \mathrm{a}} T\left({ }^{\circ} \mathrm{F}\right)$, where $T\left({ }^{\circ} \mathrm{F}\right)$ denotes the temperature in ${ }^{\circ} \mathrm{F}$. In the temperature ranges of Figs. A-9 and A-9E, $c_{p \mathrm{a}}$ can be taken as $1.005 \mathrm{~kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \cdot \mathrm{K}$ and $0.24 \mathrm{Btu} / \mathrm{lb} \cdot{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{R}$, respectively. On Figs. A-9 the enthalpy of the water vapor $h_{\mathrm{v}}$ is evaluated as $h_{\mathrm{g}}$ at the dry-bulb temperature of the mixture from Table A-2 or A-2E, as appropriate.

- Another important parameter on psychrometer charts is the wet-bulb temperature. As illustrated by Figs. A-9, constant $T_{\mathrm{wb}}$ lines run from the upper left to the lower right of the chart. The relationship between the wet-bulb temperature and other chart quantities is provided by Eq. 12.48. The wet-bulb temperature can be used in this equation in place of the adiabatic-saturation temperature for the states of moist air located on Figs. A-9.


FIG. 12.9 Psychrometric chart.
- Lines of constant wet-bulb temperature are approximately lines of constant mixture enthalpy per unit mass of dry air. This feature can be brought out by study of the energy balance for the adiabatic saturator, Eq. 12.50. Since the contribution of the energy entering the adiabatic saturator with the makeup water is normally much smaller than that of the moist air, the enthalpy of the entering moist air is very nearly equal to the enthalpy of the saturated mixture exiting. Accordingly, all states with the same value of the wetbulb temperature (adiabatic-saturation temperature) have nearly the same value for the mixture enthalpy per unit mass of dry air. Although Figs. A-9 ignore this slight effect, some psychrometric charts are drawn to show the departure of lines of constant wet-bulb temperature from lines of constant mixture enthalpy.
- As shown on Fig. 12.9, psychrometric charts also provide lines representing volume per unit mass of dry air, $V / m_{\mathrm{a}}$. Figures A-9 and A-9E give this quantity in units of $\mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{kg}$ and $\mathrm{ft}^{3} / \mathrm{lb}$, respectively. These specific volume lines can be interpreted as giving the volume of dry air or of water vapor, per unit mass of dry air, since each mixture component is considered to fill the entire volume.

The psychrometric chart is easily used.

# FOR EXAMPLE 

A psychrometer indicates that in a classroom the dry-bulb temperature is $68^{\circ} \mathrm{F}$ and the wet-bulb temperature is $60^{\circ} \mathrm{F}$. Locating the mixture state on Fig. A-9E corresponding to the intersection of these temperatures, we read $\omega=0.0092 \mathrm{lb}$ (vapor) $/ \mathrm{lb}$ (dry air) and $\phi=63 \%$.

### 12.8 Analyzing Air-Conditioning Processes

The purpose of the present section is to study typical air-conditioning processes using the psychrometric principles developed in this chapter. Specific illustrations are provided in the form of solved examples involving control volumes at steady state. In each example, the methodology introduced in Sec. 12.8.1 is employed to arrive at the solution.

To reinforce principles developed in this chapter, the psychrometric parameters required by these examples are determined in most cases using tabular data from Appendix tables. Where a full psychrometric chart solution is not also provided, we recommend the example be solved using the chart, checking results with values from the solution presented.

### 12.8.1 Applying Mass and Energy Balances to Air-Conditioning Systems

The object of this section is to illustrate the use of the conservation of mass and conservation of energy principles in analyzing systems involving mixtures of dry air and water vapor in which a condensed water phase may be present. The same basic solution approach that has been used in thermodynamic analyses considered thus far is applicable. The only new aspect is the use of the special vocabulary and parameters of psychrometrics.

Systems that accomplish air-conditioning processes such as heating, cooling, humidification, or dehumidification are normally analyzed on a control volume basis. To consider a typical analysis, refer to Fig. 12.10, which shows a two-inlet, single-exit control volume at steady


FIG. 12.10 Systems for conditioning moist air.state. A moist air stream enters at 1, a moist air stream exits at 2, and a water-only stream enters (or exits) at 3. The water-only stream may be a liquid or a vapor. Heat transfer at the rate $\dot{Q}_{\mathrm{cv}}$ can occur between the control volume and its surroundings. Depending on the application, the value of $\dot{Q}_{\mathrm{cv}}$ might be positive, negative, or zero.

Mass Balance At steady state, the amounts of dry air and water vapor contained within the control volume cannot vary. Thus, for each component individually it is necessary for the total incoming and outgoing mass flow rates to be equal. That is,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\dot{m}_{\mathrm{a} 1} & =\dot{m}_{\mathrm{a} 2} & & (\text { dry air }) \\
\dot{m}_{\mathrm{v} 1}+\dot{m}_{\mathrm{w}} & =\dot{m}_{\mathrm{v} 2} & & (\text { water })
\end{aligned}
$$

For simplicity, the constant mass flow rate of the dry air is denoted by $\dot{m}_{\mathrm{a}}$. The mass flow rates of the water vapor can be expressed conveniently in terms of humidity ratios as $\dot{m}_{\mathrm{v} 1}=\omega_{1} \dot{m}_{\mathrm{a}}$ and $\dot{m}_{\mathrm{v} 2}=\omega_{2} \dot{m}_{\mathrm{a}}$. With these expressions, the mass balance for water becomes

$$
\dot{m}_{\mathrm{w}}=\dot{m}_{\mathrm{a}}\left(\omega_{2}-\omega_{1}\right) \quad \text { (water) }
$$

When water is added at $3, \omega_{2}$ is greater than $\omega_{1}$.

# TAKE NOTE... 

As indicated by the developments of Sec. 12.8.1, several simplifying assumptions are made when analyzing air-conditioning systems considered in Examples 12.10-12.14 to follow. They include:

- The control volume is at steady state.
- Moist air streams are ideal gas mixtures of dry air and water vapor adhering to the Dalton model.
- Flow is one-dimensional where mass crosses the boundary of the control volume, and the effects of kinetic and potential energy at these locations are neglected.
- The only work is flow work (Sec. 4.4.2) where mass crosses the boundary of the control volume.

Energy Balance Assuming $\dot{W}_{\mathrm{cv}}=0$ and ignoring all kinetic and potential energy effects, the energy rate balance reduces at steady state to

$$
0=\dot{Q}_{\mathrm{cv}}+\left(\dot{m}_{\mathrm{a}} h_{\mathrm{a} 1}+\dot{m}_{\mathrm{v} 1} h_{\mathrm{v} 1}\right)+\dot{m}_{\mathrm{w}} h_{\mathrm{w}}-\left(\dot{m}_{\mathrm{a}} h_{\mathrm{a} 2}+\dot{m}_{\mathrm{v} 2} h_{\mathrm{v} 2}\right)
$$

In this equation, the entering and exiting moist air streams are regarded as ideal gas mixtures of dry air and water vapor.

Equation 12.53 can be cast into a form that is particularly convenient for the analysis of air-conditioning systems. First, with Eq. 12.47 the enthalpies of the entering and exiting water vapor can be evaluated as the saturated vapor enthalpies corresponding to the temperatures $T_{1}$ and $T_{2}$, respectively, giving

$$
0=\dot{Q}_{\mathrm{cv}}+\left(\dot{m}_{\mathrm{a}} h_{\mathrm{a} 1}+\dot{m}_{\mathrm{v} 1} h_{\mathrm{g} 1}\right)+\dot{m}_{\mathrm{w}} h_{\mathrm{w}}-\left(\dot{m}_{\mathrm{a}} h_{\mathrm{a} 2}+\dot{m}_{\mathrm{v} 2} h_{\mathrm{g} 2}\right)
$$

Then, with $\dot{m}_{\mathrm{v} 1}=\omega_{1} \dot{m}_{\mathrm{a}}$ and $\dot{m}_{\mathrm{v} 2}=\omega_{2} \dot{m}_{\mathrm{a}}$, the equation can be expressed as

$$
0=\dot{Q}_{\mathrm{cv}}+\dot{m}_{\mathrm{a}}\left(h_{\mathrm{a} 1}+\omega_{1} h_{\mathrm{g} 1}\right)+\dot{m}_{\mathrm{w}} h_{\mathrm{w}}-\dot{m}_{\mathrm{a}}\left(h_{\mathrm{a} 2}+\omega_{2} h_{\mathrm{g} 2}\right)
$$

Finally, introducing Eq. 12.52, the energy rate balance becomes

$$
0=\dot{Q}_{\mathrm{cv}}+\dot{m}_{\mathrm{a}}\left[\left(h_{\mathrm{a} 1}-h_{\mathrm{a} 2}\right)+\underline{\omega_{1} h_{\mathrm{g} 1}+\left(\omega_{2}-\omega_{1}\right) h_{\mathrm{w}}-\omega_{2} h_{\mathrm{g} 2}}\right]
$$

The first underlined term of Eq. 12.55 can be evaluated from Tables A-22 giving the ideal gas properties of air. Alternatively, since relatively small temperature differences are normally encountered in the class of systems under present consideration, this term can be evaluated as
$h_{\mathrm{a} 1}-h_{\mathrm{a} 2}=c_{p \mathrm{~h}}\left(T_{1}-T_{2}\right)$, where $c_{p \mathrm{~h}}$ is a constant value for the specific heat of dry air. The second underlined term of Eq. 12.55 can be evaluated using steam table data together with known values for $\omega_{1}$ and $\omega_{2}$. As illustrated in discussions to follow, Eq. 12.55 also can be evaluated using the psychrometric chart or $I T$.

# 12.8.2 Conditioning Moist Air at Constant Composition 

Building air-conditioning systems frequently heat or cool a moist air stream with no change in the amount of water vapor present. In such cases the humidity ratio $\omega$ remains constant, while relative humidity and other moist air parameters vary. Example 12.10 gives an elementary illustration using the methodology of Sec. 12.8.1.

## EXAMPLE 12.10 | Heating Moist Air in a Duct

Moist air enters a duct at $10^{\circ} \mathrm{C}, 80 \%$ relative humidity, and a volumetric flow rate of $150 \mathrm{~m}^{3} / \mathrm{min}$. The mixture is heated as it flows through the duct and exits at $30^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. No moisture is added or removed, and the mixture pressure remains approximately constant at 1 bar. For steady-state operation, determine (a) the rate of heat transfer, in $\mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{min}$, and (b) the relative humidity at the exit. Changes in kinetic and potential energy can be ignored.

## Solution

Known Moist air that enters a duct at $10^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and $\phi=80 \%$ with a volumetric flow rate of $150 \mathrm{~m}^{3} / \mathrm{min}$ is heated at constant pressure and exits at $30^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. No moisture is added or removed.

Find Determine the rate of heat transfer, in $\mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{min}$, and the relative humidity at the exit.

## Schematic and Given Data:



FIG. E12.10a

## Engineering Model

1. The control volume shown in the accompanying figure operates at steady state.
2. The changes in kinetic and potential energy between inlet and exit can be ignored and $\dot{W}_{\mathrm{cv}}=0$.
3. The entering and exiting moist air streams are regarded as ideal gas mixtures adhering to the Dalton model.

## Analysis

a. The heat transfer rate $\dot{Q}_{\mathrm{cv}}$ can be determined from the mass and energy rate balances. At steady state, the amounts of dry air and water vapor contained within the control volume cannot vary. Thus, for each component individually it is necessary for the incoming and outgoing mass flow rates to be equal. That is,

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\dot{m}_{\mathrm{a} 1}=\dot{m}_{\mathrm{a} 2} & \text { (dry air) } \\
\dot{m}_{\mathrm{v} 1}=\dot{m}_{\mathrm{v} 2} & \text { (water vapor) }
\end{array}
$$

For simplicity, the constant mass flow rates of the dry air and water vapor are denoted, respectively, by $\dot{m}_{\mathrm{a}}$ and $\dot{m}_{\mathrm{v}}$. From these considerations, it can be concluded that the humidity ratio is the same at the inlet and exit: $\omega_{1}=\omega_{2}$.

The steady-state form of the energy rate balance reduces with assumption 2 to

$$
0=\dot{Q}_{\mathrm{cv}}-\dot{W}_{\mathrm{cv}}^{0}+\left(\dot{m}_{\mathrm{a}} h_{\mathrm{a} 1}+\dot{m}_{\mathrm{v}} h_{\mathrm{v} 1}\right)-\left(\dot{m}_{\mathrm{a}} h_{\mathrm{a} 2}+\dot{m}_{\mathrm{v}} h_{\mathrm{v} 2}\right)
$$

In writing this equation, the incoming and outgoing moist air streams are regarded as ideal gas mixtures of dry air and water vapor.

Solving for $\dot{Q}_{\mathrm{cv}}$

$$
\dot{Q}_{\mathrm{cv}}=\dot{m}_{\mathrm{a}}\left(h_{\mathrm{a} 2}-h_{\mathrm{a} 1}\right)+\dot{m}_{\mathrm{v}}\left(h_{\mathrm{v} 2}-h_{\mathrm{v} 1}\right)
$$

Noting that $\dot{m}_{\mathrm{v}}=\omega \dot{m}_{\mathrm{a}}$, where $\omega$ is the humidity ratio, the expression for $\dot{Q}_{\mathrm{cv}}$ can be written in the form

$$
\dot{Q}_{\mathrm{cv}}=\dot{m}_{\mathrm{a}}\left[\left(h_{\mathrm{a} 2}-h_{\mathrm{a} 1}\right)+\omega\left(h_{\mathrm{v} 2}-h_{\mathrm{v} 1}\right)\right]
$$

To evaluate $\dot{Q}_{\mathrm{cv}}$ from this expression requires the specific enthalpies of the dry air and water vapor at the inlet and exit, the mass flow rate of the dry air, and the humidity ratio.

The specific enthalpies of the dry air are obtained from Table A-22 at the inlet and exit temperatures $T_{1}$ and $T_{2}$, respectively: $h_{\mathrm{a} 1}=283.1 \mathrm{~kJ} / \mathrm{kg}, h_{\mathrm{a} 2}=303.2 \mathrm{~kJ} / \mathrm{kg}$. The specific enthalpies of the water vapor are found using $h_{\mathrm{v}} \approx h_{\mathrm{p}}$ and data from Table A-2 at $T_{1}$ and $T_{2}$, respectively: $h_{\mathrm{g} 1}=2519.8 \mathrm{~kJ} / \mathrm{kg}, h_{\mathrm{g} 2}=2556.3 \mathrm{~kJ} / \mathrm{kg}$.

The mass flow rate of the dry air can be determined from the volumetric flow rate at the inlet $(\mathrm{AV})_{1}$

$$
\dot{m}_{\mathrm{a}}=\frac{(\mathrm{AV})_{1}}{v_{\mathrm{a} 1}}
$$
In this equation, $v_{\mathrm{a} 1}$ is the specific volume of the dry air evaluated at $T_{1}$ and the partial pressure of the dry air $p_{\mathrm{a} 1}$. Using the ideal gas equation of state

$$
v_{\mathrm{a} 1}=\frac{(\bar{R} / M) T_{1}}{p_{\mathrm{a} 1}}
$$

The partial pressure $p_{\mathrm{a} 1}$ can be determined from the mixture pressure $p$ and the partial pressure of the water vapor $p_{\mathrm{v} 1}: p_{\mathrm{a} 1}=p-p_{\mathrm{v} 1}$. To find $p_{\mathrm{v} 1}$, use the given inlet relative humidity and the saturation pressure at $10^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ from Table A-2

$$
p_{\mathrm{v} 1}=\phi_{1} p_{\mathrm{g} 1}=(0.8)(0.01228 \mathrm{bar})=0.0098 \mathrm{bar}
$$

Since the mixture pressure is 1 bar, it follows that $p_{\mathrm{a} 1}=0.9902$ bar. The specific volume of the dry air is then

$$
v_{\mathrm{a} 1}=\frac{\left(\frac{8314 \mathrm{~N} \cdot \mathrm{~m}}{28.97 \mathrm{~kg} \cdot \mathrm{~K}}\right)(283 \mathrm{~K})}{\left(0.9902 \times 10^{5} \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}^{2}\right)}=0.82 \mathrm{~m}^{3} / \mathrm{kg}
$$

Using this value, the mass flow rate of the dry air is

$$
\dot{m}_{\mathrm{a}}=\frac{150 \mathrm{~m}^{3} / \mathrm{min}}{0.82 \mathrm{~m}^{3} / \mathrm{kg}}=182.9 \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{min}
$$

The humidity ratio $\omega$ can be found from

$$
\begin{aligned}
\omega & =0.622\left(\frac{p_{\mathrm{v} 1}}{p-p_{\mathrm{v} 1}}\right)=0.622\left(\frac{0.0098}{1-0.0098}\right) \\
& =0.00616 \frac{\mathrm{~kg}(\text { vapor })}{\mathrm{kg}(\text { dry air })}
\end{aligned}
$$

Finally, substituting values into Eq. (a) we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\dot{Q}_{\mathrm{cv}} & =182.9[(303.2-283.1)+(0.00616)(2556.3-2519.8)] \\
& =3717 \mathrm{~kJ} / \mathrm{min}
\end{aligned}
$$

b. The states of the water vapor at the duct inlet and exit are located on the accompanying $T$ - $v$ diagram. Since the composition of the moist air and the mixture pressure remain constant, the partial pressure of the water vapor at the exit equals the partial pressure of the water vapor at the inlet: $p_{\mathrm{v} 2}=p_{\mathrm{v} 1}=0.0098$ bar. The relative humidity at the exit is then

$$
\phi_{2}=\frac{p_{\mathrm{v} 2}}{p_{\mathrm{g} 2}}=\frac{0.0098}{0.04246}=0.231(23.1 \%)
$$

where $p_{\mathrm{g} 2}$ is from Table A-2 at $30^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$.
Alternative Psychrometric Chart Solution Let us consider an alternative solution using the psychrometric chart. As shown on the sketch of the psychrometric chart, Fig. E12.10b, the state of the moist air at the inlet is defined by $\phi_{1}=80 \%$ and a dry-bulb temperature of $10^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. From the solution to part (a), we know that the humidity ratio has the same value at the exit as at the inlet. Accordingly, the state of the moist air at the exit is fixed by $\omega_{2}=\omega_{1}$ and a dry-bulb temperature of $30^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. By inspection of Fig. A-9, the relative humidity at the duct exit is about $23 \%$ and, thus, in agreement with the result of part (b).

The rate of heat transfer can be evaluated from the psychrometric chart using the following expression obtained by rearranging Eq. (a) of part (a) to read

$$
\dot{Q}_{\mathrm{cv}}=\dot{m}_{\mathrm{a}}\left[\left(h_{\mathrm{a}}+\omega h_{\mathrm{v}}\right)_{2}-\left(h_{\mathrm{a}}+\omega h_{\mathrm{v}}\right)_{1}\right]
$$

To evaluate $\dot{Q}_{\mathrm{cv}}$ from this expression requires values for the mixture enthalpy per unit mass of dry air $\left(h_{\mathrm{a}}+\omega h_{\mathrm{v}}\right)$ at the inlet and exit. These can be determined by inspection of the psychrometric
chart, Fig. A-9, as $\left(h_{\mathrm{a}}+\omega h_{\mathrm{v}}\right)_{1}=25.7 \mathrm{~kJ} / \mathrm{kg}$ (dry air), $\left(h_{\mathrm{a}}+\omega h_{\mathrm{v}}\right)_{2}=$ $45.9 \mathrm{~kJ} / \mathrm{kg}$ (dry air).

Using the specific volume value $v_{\mathrm{a} 1}$ at the inlet state read from the chart together with the given volumetric flow rate at the inlet, the mass flow rate of the dry air is found as

$$
\dot{m}_{\mathrm{a}}=\frac{150 \mathrm{~m}^{3} / \mathrm{min}}{0.81 \mathrm{~m}^{3} / \mathrm{kg}(\text { dry air })}=185 \frac{\mathrm{~kg}(\text { dry air })}{\mathrm{min}}
$$

Substituting values into the energy rate balance, Eq. (b), we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\dot{Q}_{\mathrm{cv}} & =185 \frac{\mathrm{~kg}(\text { dry air })}{\min }(45.9-25.7) \frac{\mathrm{kJ}}{\mathrm{~kg}(\text { dry air })} \\
& =3737 \frac{\mathrm{~kJ}}{\min }
\end{aligned}
$$

which agrees closely with the result obtained in part (a), as expected.


FIG. E12.10b
(1) The first underlined term in this equation for $\dot{Q}_{\mathrm{cv}}$ is evaluated with specific enthalpies from the ideal gas table for air, Table A-22. Steam table data are used to evaluate the second underlined term. Note that the different datums for enthalpy underlying these tables cancel because each of the two terms involves enthalpy differences only. Since the specific heat $c_{p a}$ for dry air varies only slightly over the interval from 10 to $30^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ (Table A-20), the specific enthalpy change of the dry air could be evaluated alternatively with $c_{p a}=1.005 \mathrm{~kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \cdot \mathrm{K}$.
